channel.title: NYT > Health
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Can You Become Immune to the Coronavirus?
item.description: It’s likely you can, at least for some period of time. That is opening new opportunities for testing and treatment.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:description: A recovered coronavirus patient donated plasma at the Hainan Blood Center in Haikou, China, in February.

item.title: Ventilators and Coronavirus: Amid Desperation, Calls Grow for Federal Intervention
item.description: President Trump wants the private sector to fill the urgent need for the lifesaving devices. Experts say that strategy may doom the thousands who will need them in the coming weeks.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Jacobs, Neal E. Boudette, Matt Richtel and Nicholas Kulish
item.media:description: A lone ventilator at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center on Monday in New York, which will be converted into a 1,000-bed hospital.

item.title: Gilead Withdraws Request for Special Orphan Status on Experimental Coronavirus Treatment
item.description: Critics said the company was profiteering from the coronavirus pandemic by seeking tax and monopoly benefits under a program intended to encourage drug development for rare diseases.
item.dc:creator: Katie Thomas

item.title: You’ve Got Mail. Will You Get the Coronavirus?
item.description: The practice of disinfecting mail dates back to the invention of quarantine. There’s little evidence it needs to be invoked today.
item.dc:creator: Nicola Twilley
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Jordan Gale for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mail carrier in Manhattan on Monday.

item.title: Live Coronavirus Updates and Coverage
item.description: Gov. Andrew Cuomo said there were early signs that New York’s restrictions on gatherings could be slowing the virus but that more needed to be done in New York City.

item.title: Coronavirus Symptoms Full List: What Are They? Is There a Cure?
item.description: Here’s what to do if you feel sick and are worried it may be the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: Experts have urged people not to panic over the coronavirus. “The mantra is, ‘Keep calm and carry on,’” said Dr. Marguerite Neill, an infectious disease expert at Brown University.

item.title: Coronavirus Can Be Stopped Only by Harsh Steps, Experts Say
item.description: Scientists who have fought pandemics describe difficult measures needed to defend the United States against a fast-moving pathogen.
item.dc:creator: Donald G. McNeil Jr.
item.media:credit: Stephanie Keith for The New York Times

item.title: Obamacare Turns 10. Here’s a Look at What Works and Doesn’t.
item.description: With the coronavirus, a new Supreme Court case and a blistering election debate, the Affordable Care Act is facing challenges as never before. We looked at how it’s held up to its promise.
item.dc:creator: Abby Goodnough, Reed Abelson, Margot Sanger-Katz and Sarah Kliff
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
item.media:description: President Obama signing the Affordable Care Act into law at the White House on March 23, 2010.

item.title: The Unseen Survivors of Thalidomide Want to Be Heard
item.description: The U.S. was supposed to have escaped the devastation of a drug that caused birth defects in babies overseas. This is the almost forgotten story of its toll in America.
item.dc:creator: Katie Thomas
item.media:credit: Jenn Ackerman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Carolyn Farmer Sampson holding a photo of herself from when she was just a few months old in her home in Eagan, Minn.

item.title: How to Sleep With Coronavirus Anxiety
item.description: Sleep has never been more important. Here are our most concrete recommendations for getting some.
item.dc:creator: Adam Popescu
item.media:credit: David Brandon Geeting for The New York Times

item.title: How to Get Health Insurance if Worried About Coronavirus or Unemployment
item.description: There are more options for getting coverage than in past economic crises.
item.dc:creator: Margot Sanger-Katz and Reed Abelson
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)

item.title: A Homeless Family Navigates a Life Warped by the Coronavirus
item.description: April Goode and four of her children moved into a hotel room in New Jersey in February. She had no job and no car. Then the pandemic hit.
item.dc:creator: Mihir Zaveri
item.media:credit: Erica Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: April Goode, 39, in the hotel room where she has been living with her son, Ethan, 9, and three other children last month. The coronavirus outbreak has since brought added challenges.

item.title: Becoming a Man, Virtually
item.description: We couldn’t have guests, but the bar mitzvah ceremony would go on.
item.dc:creator: Deb Levy
item.media:description: Zane Levy’s bar mitzvah was live-streamed on Saturday because of the coronavirus restrictions on gathering.

item.title: Jane Goodall Is Self-Isolating, Too
item.description: She’s in England, in the house she grew up in, and she has a few thoughts about chimpanzees, the coronavirus pandemic and the loo paper shortage.
item.dc:creator: James Gorman
item.media:description: British primatologist Jane Goodall in the science museum CosmoCaixa of Barcelona in 2018.

item.title: Lawmakers Question Start-Ups on At-Home Kits for Coronavirus Testing
item.description: The makers of unauthorized kits designed for consumers to collect their own saliva or throat swabs faced scrutiny from Congress.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Singer
item.media:description: Everlywell said it would provide its kits to health care providers and hospitals.

item.title: ‘A Week of Snow Days’? Ha! Families Deal With Cabin Fever
item.description: As people become hostages in their own homes, hired clowns and costume nights may not be enough to maintain sanity.
item.dc:creator: Nellie Bowles

item.title: How ‘Muscle Memory’ May Help Keep Us Fit
item.description: Muscles may “remember” in ways that will allow us to regain fitness once gyms reopen and we start working out again.
item.dc:creator: Gretchen Reynolds

item.title: Shutdown Spotlights Economic Cost of Saving Lives
item.description: President Trump and others have asked if halting normal life and commerce to fight the coronavirus is worth the cost. Here’s how economists figure it.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Porter and Jim Tankersley
item.media:credit: Chona Kasinger for The New York Times
item.media:description: Downtown Seattle was virtually empty on a Friday in mid-March after the region became a U.S. beachhead for the new coronavirus.

item.title: Spring Breaker Who Said, 'If I Get Corona, I Get Corona,' Apologizes
item.description: A beachgoer whose defiance of social distancing guidelines drew widespread attention said that he had not been “aware of the severity of my actions and comments.”
item.dc:creator: Aimee Ortiz
item.media:credit: Saul Martinez for The New York Times
item.media:description: College students at a bar in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., on March 11.

item.title: What I Learned When My Husband Got Sick With Coronavirus
item.description: Our world became one of isolation, round-the-clock care, panic and uncertainty — even as society carried on around us with all too few changes.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Lustig

item.title: Medicare Is Updating Coverage to Help in the Coronavirus Crisis
item.description: With its beneficiaries among the most at risk for Covid-19, the agency is relaxing some rules.
item.dc:creator: Mark Miller
item.category: Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services
item.media:description: Health care workers handling a coronavirus test at a drive-through station in Stamford, Conn.

item.title: Brightening Up Coronavirus Quarantine With Christmas Spirit
item.description: Families are decking the halls to bring light in a dark time.
item.dc:creator: Blane Bachelor
item.media:description: Matt Carino, a lighting design student, put up this display at his home in Montclair, N.J. “I wanted to send a simple, strong and positive message to the community,” he said.

item.title: Some Doctors Stockpile Trial Coronavirus Drugs for Themselves, States Say
item.description: The stockpiling has become so worrisome that pharmacy boards in many states have issued emergency restrictions on how the drugs can be dispensed.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Gabler
item.media:credit: Ramin Rahimian for The New York Times
item.media:description: A handful of state pharmacy boards have issued emergency restrictions on how the drugs can be dispensed.

item.title: Coronavirus in China: Hubei Province Lockdown Eased After 2 Months
item.description: The province will let people outside Wuhan leave for the first time since late January. Despite the official sign of confidence, many fear the virus is still spreading silently.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang and Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:description: Workers with containers of disinfectant preparing on Tuesday to spray the central railway station in Wuhan, the city in Hubei Province that emerged in January as the epicenter of the coronavirus outbreak.

item.title: Rome’s Homeless Don’t Have the Luxury of Staying Home
item.description: How do you wash your hands without a sink? Stock up on food without money? Or shelter in place when you live on the streets? Charities in the Italian capital are struggling to respond.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Alessandro Penso for The New York Times
item.media:description: Piazza dei Crociferi in Rome on Saturday. There are about 8,000 homeless people in the Italian capital.

item.title: A Medical Class ‘Minted by the Pandemic’
item.description: Across the nation, medical students are graduating directly into the path of an epic health crisis.
item.dc:creator: Emma Goldberg
item.media:credit: Stephen Speranza for The New York Times
item.media:description: David Edelman, a fifth-year medical student at Columbia University, helped establish the Covid-19 Student Service Corps to support healthcare providers. “There’s so much to be done,” he said.

item.title: Who Should Be Saved First? Experts Offer Ethical Guidance
item.description: Well before rationing caused by coronavirus, protocols were established about “who lives and who dies.”
item.dc:creator: Austin Frakt
item.media:description: Ventilators under assembly at a medical supply company in Britain. The lack of such equipment has already created wrenching decisions for health care workers in Italy.

item.title: Some Pregnant Women in New York City Will Have to Deliver Babies Alone
item.description: “I have not stopped crying,” said an expectant mother who learned that her husband could not be with her when she gives birth.
item.dc:creator: Christina Caron and Katie Van Syckle
item.media:description: NewYork-Presbyterian has barred partners from labor and delivery rooms throughout its network.

item.title: Cooking Through a Crisis With Grandma, Virtually
item.description: At a moment when the present is terrifying and the future is uncertain, we’re returning to the recipes of the past.
item.dc:creator: Ali Jaffe
item.media:description: Ali Jaffe cooks in her Brooklyn kitchen with guidance from her grandmother, Roslyn Jaffe, using FaceTime.

item.title: Getting Through, Making Memories and Being the Grown-Ups
item.description: You can’t change the world, but you can help shape the way your children experience this and remember it. And you will. You’re the person they need.
item.dc:creator: Perri Klass, M.D.

item.title: What Does Our Body Temperature Say About Our Health?
item.description: Humans seem to have cooled over the past 150 years. What does that mean for us now?
item.dc:creator: Kim Tingley
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

item.title: Welcome to the Virosphere
item.description: SARS-CoV-2, the cause of the pandemic, belongs to one of 6,828 named species of virus. Hundreds of thousands more species are known, with perhaps trillions waiting to be found.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer

item.title: As Fleeing New Yorkers Are Told to Quarantine, Trump Says U.S. Should Reopen ‘by Easter’
item.description: Fleeing New Yorkers told to quarantine as Trump says the U.S. should reopen ‘by Easter.’
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

item.title: Grieving the Losses of Coronavirus
item.description: In addition to the tragic losses of life and health and jobs we are grieving the losses of weddings, sports and the ability to buy eggs or get a haircut.
item.dc:creator: Lori Gottlieb

item.title: Coronavirus Patients in Limbo as Gilead Suspends Emergency Drug Access
item.description: The company says it will switch to a broader approach for its experimental drug, remdesivir. But it was overwhelmed by demand for a potential treatment promoted by President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Katie Thomas
item.media:description: Gilead Sciences headquarters in Foster City, Calif.

item.title: Singalongs From Windowsills Lift Spirits During Coronavirus Crisis
item.description: Following an example set by Europeans who sang from balconies, some homebound Americans are communally belting out tunes from their windows.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Mele and Neil Vigdor
item.media:description: A man claps as Beatriz Berodia, a Spanish blues singer, performs from her balcony in Madrid. Some Americans who are homebound because of the coronavirus are also taking up communal singing.

item.title: Eleven States Now Letting Uninsured Sign Up for Obamacare
item.description: More coronavirus care will be covered in many states. Federal officials are considering similar action for the state markets they run.
item.dc:creator: Margot Sanger-Katz and Reed Abelson
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)

item.title: Medical Students, Sidelined for Now, Find New Ways to Fight Coronavirus
item.description: After medical schools ended contact with patients, disappointed students organized to collect masks, work at call centers and offer child care to health workers.
item.dc:creator: Penina Krieger and Abby Goodnough
item.media:description: Dustin Lamb, right, a student at the University of Colorado Medical School, accepted medical supplies during a public drive in Denver on Sunday.

item.title: Coronavirus Makes Daily Life Confounding. Here Are Some Answers.
item.description: Welcome to Dilemmas, where we find solutions to your toughest quandaries.
item.dc:creator: Jodi Kantor
item.media:description: Lise King is a Select Board member in Provincetown, Mass., where plane after plane has been arriving in the off-season.

item.title: These Doctors Have Specialties. Fighting Coronavirus Wasn’t One of Them.
item.description: The pandemic’s spread is creating new challenges for doctors who usually care primarily for patients with particular medical needs.
item.dc:creator: Emma Goldberg
item.media:credit: Johnathon Kelso for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Scott Isaacs, an endocrinologist in Atlanta, said he had been barraged with calls from his diabetes patients asking about how to get tested and treated for the coronavirus.

item.title: Supplements for Coronavirus Probably Won’t Help, and May Harm
item.description: Worried Americans are scrambling to buy wellness products they think will protect against coronavirus. Some may do harm.
item.dc:creator: Anahad O’Connor
item.media:credit: Chester Higgins Jr./The New York Times

item.title: Thalidomide Use Did Happen Here, These Americans Say
item.description: They believe they were harmed in the thalidomide crisis of the 1950s and 1960s.
item.dc:creator: Katie Thomas
item.media:credit: Audra Melton for The New York Times

item.title: The Story of Thalidomide in the U.S., Told Through Documents
item.description: A trove of archival records shows how in the early 1960s the Food and Drug Administration investigated the use of a drug that caused severe birth defects.
item.dc:creator: Katie Thomas

item.title: When Coronavirus Closes Your Lab, Can Science Go On?
item.description: Plenty of work can be done from home, but the pandemic is forcing some parts of the scientific process to be put on the shelf.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Bioluminescent plankton studied in the lab of David Gruber, a biologist at City University of New York.

item.title: The Medical ID Bracelet That Doesn’t Look Like One
item.description: An ID can be crucial in a medical crisis, and it doesn’t have to be something you want to hide.
item.dc:creator: Jaclyn Peiser
item.media:description: A medical ID bracelet from the line Return to Sender.

item.title: Coronavirus and Social Distancing: Take Steps to Counter the Loneliness
item.description: Attempts to avoid coronavirus can increase the risk of physical and emotional harm from limited social contact.
item.dc:creator: Jane E. Brody

item.title: Heartburn Drugs Tied to Bone Fractures in Children
item.description: Proton pump inhibitors are sometimes needed in children with reflux, but parents should be aware they may increase the risk of fractures.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bakalar

item.title: 158 Million Americans Told to Stay Home, but Trump Pledges to Keep It Short
item.description: The White House warned of an alarming spread in New York City, but the president said “our country wasn’t built to be shut down.”

item.title: Scientists Identify 69 Drugs to Test Against the Coronavirus
item.description: Two dozen of the medicines are already under investigation. Also on the list: chloroquine, a drug used to treat malaria.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer
item.media:description: A worker checking the production of chloroquine phosphate in China last month. There has been “anecdotal evidence” that chloroquine, a drug used to treat malaria, might work against the coronavirus.

item.title: With Live Sports Gone, Announcer Offers Play by Play of the Everyday
item.description: Nick Heath narrates his videos of people doing mundane things, like crossing the street, with the verve and dramatic flair of competitive sports.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz
item.media:description: Nick Heath, a rugby announcer, has been chronicling his London neighborhood with videos that have become popular on social media.

item.title: Lost Sense of Smell May Be Peculiar Clue to Coronavirus Infection
item.description: Doctor groups are recommending testing and isolation for people who lose their ability to smell and taste, even if they have no other symptoms.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.media:description: A girl removed her mask to smell the flowers on a blooming tree in Skopje, North Macedonia, on Friday. Evidence is growing that lost sense of smell and taste are peculiar telltale signs of Covid-19, the disease caused by the coronavirus.

item.title: Some Tips on How to Stay Sane in a World That Isn’t
item.description: The coronavirus outbreak has magnified all kinds of fears. Try living in the moment. Take stock of what’s working. Turn off the television.
item.dc:creator: Katherine Rosman
item.media:description: The pedestrian area of South Beach, Fla., was nearly empty on Friday after local authorities restricted non-essential activities and rolled out a midnight curfew in Miami Beach.

item.title: Plácido Domingo Says He Has the Coronavirus
item.description: “I beg everyone to be extremely careful,” the opera singer said in a Facebook post on Sunday after developing a fever and cough and testing positive for the virus.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Plácido Domingo in 2018 at the 50th anniversary of his debut at the Metropolitan Opera in New York. The opera singer, 79, disclosed on Sunday that he tested positive for the coronavirus.

item.title: Warmer Weather May Slow, but Not Halt, Coronavirus
item.description: Nature may help diminish the pandemic if aggressive measures to control the spread of infections continue, experts say. That doesn’t mean the virus won’t return.
item.dc:creator: Knvul Sheikh and Ernesto Londoño
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Empty streets of Bogotá during mandatory isolation on Saturday.

item.title: Target Apologizes for Selling N95 Masks in Seattle
item.description: The company said the masks were offered for sale “in error” at some stores in Washington State, which has been a hot spot for the coronavirus pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz
item.media:description: Gov. Jay Inslee of Washington said his office had taken action after hearing reports of N95 masks being sold at Target stores in Seattle.

item.title: Geese May Not Inspire You, but They Certainly Take Your Mind Off the Virus
item.description: Watching birds that do not practice social distancing is a nice break from washing your hands and disinfecting friends.
item.dc:creator: James Gorman and Natalie Keyssar
item.media:description: Gulls, ducks and brants, a type of goose, in Flushing Meadows Park in Queens.

item.title: As State Pleas Mount, Trump Outlines Some Federal Action; Senate Democrats Block Stimulus Package
item.description: New York State has 15,000 cases, roughly 5 percent of the pandemic’s growing global total. Senator Rand Paul tested positive for the coronavirus.
item.media:credit: Erin Scott for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Chuck Schumer speaking to reporters at the Capitol on Sunday.

item.title: Christian Siriano and Dov Charney Are Making Masks and Medical Supplies Now
item.description: Fashion designers and manufacturers are rebooting their operations to help with shortages of masks and gowns in the coronavirus pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Friedman and Jessica Testa
item.category: LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton SA
item.media:credit: Elizabeth Bick for The New York Times
item.media:description: Both tourists and New Yorkers on March 14, at the World Trade Center in New York City.

item.title: The Hottest Parties in Town Are Now Online
item.description: As many are quarantining or socially distancing themselves to curb the spread of the coronavirus, the party has moved to social media.
item.dc:creator: Sandra E. Garcia
item.media:description: D.J. D-Nice at the Guggenheim Museum in New York in 2019. He hosted a nine-hour set on his Instagram Live on Friday night that was “attended” by many celebrities.
